title: HR Analytics
text: already cleaned harmonized HRMIS data shared Government Brazil, can use standard functions produce analytical outputs. fast reliable function knows data formats expect produces summary statistics consistent way. Let’s start contract module. Suppose interested computing overall wage bill evolution time. can quickly convenient function: salary data year 2018, therefore can’t compute wage bill year. can quickly visualize annual wage bill.  Now imagine want unpack wage bill. Suppose interested decomposition establshment. can quickly function, like : just add "org_id" groups argument. can quickly plot new object:
code: library(govhr) wagebill_annual <-   bra_hrmis_contract |>      compute_fastsummary(       cols = c("net_salary_ppp"),        fns = c("sum"),        groups = c("year"),        output = "long"     )  reactable(   wagebill_annual ) wagebill_annual |>    filter(     year != 2018   ) |>    ggplot_point_line(     year,     value   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::label_number()   ) +   labs(     x = "Year",     y = "Wage Bill \n(Constant International Dollars)",     title = "Wage Bill: Annual"   ) wagebill_annual_org <-   bra_hrmis_contract |>      compute_fastsummary(       cols = c("net_salary_ppp"),        fns = c("sum"),        groups = c("org_id", "year"),        output = "long"     )  reactable(   wagebill_annual_org ) wagebill_annual_org |>    filter(     year != 2018 &       org_id %in% (unique(wagebill_annual_org$org_id) |> sample(4))   ) |>   ggplot_point_line(     year,     value,     group = org_id   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::label_number()   ) +   facet_wrap(     vars(org_id)   ) +   labs(     x = "Year",     y = "Wage Bill \n(Constant International Dollars)",     title = "Wage Bill: Annual, by Organization"   )

title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: Across many countries—especially low- middle-income settings—governments increasingly seeking adopt analytics-driven approaches public sector human resource (HR) management civil service reform. Yet government offices World Bank regional counterparts often lack standardized tools transforming raw HRMIS data formats suitable rigorous analysis. result, new diagnostic requires bespoke data cleaning, ad hoc coding decisions, country-specific scripts costly maintain difficult replicate. fragmentation makes HRM analytics expensive, slow, inconsistent. also limits ability governments development partners—including World Bank—compare results across time, sectors, countries, build reusable analytics pipelines. article describes standard approach harmonizing human resource management information system (HRMIS) data, organized three main modules: Organization, Worker, Contract. contents module described vignette("standard_dictionary"). article, provide set helper functions support harmonization process across modules. users prepare HRMIS data according standard, teams can immediately apply automated tools data quality control well dynamic reproducible reports workforce structure dynamics, pay compensation analytics, establishment control monitoring, staffing distribution analysis. vignette, harmonization.Rmd, presents practical workflow transforming raw HRMIS extracts standardized modules. provides governments clear, repeatable procedure preparing data advanced analytics can deployed rapidly consistently—reducing costs, increasing comparability, strengthening evidence-based HR decision making. harmonization workflow demonstrated shows : map raw administrative HR variables standardized public sector schema, recode local classifications (education, occupation, contract type) cross-country taxonomies, generate unique persistent identifiers workers, organizations, contracts, attach missing metadata country codes, administrative hierarchies, reference dates, structure cleaned data three standard HRMIS modules, validate outputs HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary. following procedure, governments World Bank teams can unlock common analytics ecosystem standardized public sector HR data feeds directly automated dashboards, diagnostic tools, monitoring systems—enabling faster, cheaper, consistent evidence-based HR reform.

title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: goal harmonization process establish consistent standardized structure cleaned HR datasets, ensuring analytics supporting government human resources management common analytical foundation. many client countries, HRM analytics conducted ad-hoc, highly customized manner varies consultant, ministry, year, even dataset. leads high analytical costs, limited comparability time across institutions, significant barriers scaling evidence-based human resource reform. harmonization framework addresses challenges directly. defining clear data dictionary set standardized transformations, governments can prepare HRMIS data format analytically ready fully compatible tools provided govhr package. ensures: Reproducible transparent workflows Cross-country cross-institution comparability Automatic generation quality checks dashboards Reduced data preparation cost new engagement remainder section documents harmonization steps three core modules derived data dictionary: Contract Module Worker Module Organization Module module represents specific level analysis defined dictionary constructed directly raw HRMIS data.

title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: Contract Module foundational component harmonized payroll dataset. purpose module extract structure information unique contract, reference date level, defined data dictionary. “contract record” refers worker–contract relationship specific reference period (usually month–year), capturing contractual characteristics governing worker’s employment time. practice, raw HRMIS data typically mixes variables different conceptual levels—worker attributes, position attributes, contract terms, payroll events, sometimes even one-administrative transactions. Working payroll HRMIS data many developing-country contexts often involves large datasets—sometimes millions records spanning multiple years. data volumes can quickly overwhelm standard analytical workflows handled using efficient tools. R, several paradigms manipulating two-dimensional data. purposes tutorial, rely data.table package tasks computationally intensive. time writing, data.table remains gold standard high-performance data processing R, offering exceptional speed, efficient memory use, expressive syntax tailored large datasets. Although dplyr package tidyverse ecosystem widely used favored readability intuitive grammar, operations large payroll datasets can substantially slower using dplyr alone. ensure reproducibility, performance, scalability—especially teams limited computational resources—adopt data.table primary engine harmonization. However, also use dplyr functions performance improved ensure code readability. bra_hrmis data written Portuguese might require translation English ease understanding. One option use LLM like ChatGPT get quick 34 columns. Alternatively polyglotr R package provides suite functions support translation. can applied follows: first step handling raw payroll dataset find individual identifies countract time period unique. begin looking bra_hrmis object . table previous glimpse(), can see CPF MATRICULA variables likely candidates identify contracts uniquely. quick check follows: clearly shows MATRICULA contract ID CPF possibly identifier worker, latter come handy harmonization worker module. Now, can begin creating set variables defined standard_dictionary vignette. often useful begin creating derived variables. four sets derived variables within dictionary: Industrial Standard Classification Occupation (ISCO) variables, .e. occupation_isconame, occupation_iscocode derived original occupation variables occupation_native, occupation_english. apply polyglotr::google_translate() function convert Portuguese named occupations English well use LabourR::classify_occupation() function classify occupations level-4 isco names. date variables (ref_date, start_date, end_date) often serial 5-digit format need standardized used preparing compensation variables time-variant. , create date variables: compensation variables .e. gross_salary_ppp, base_salary_ppp, net_salary_ppp derived local currency equivalents gross_salary_lcu, base_salary_lcu, net_salary_lcu. provide function called convert_constant_ppp() well macro_indicators dataset package perform transformations nominal variables (.e. _lcu) real equivalents (_ppp). contract type variable TIPO_CONTRATO needs reclassified according dictionary, contract_type. follows: Let’s data.table join contract_dict bra_hrmis Now derived variables contract module created, ready create rest variables finalize module. final data looks like:
code: raw_dictionary <-    tibble(raw_colnames_pt = colnames(bra_hrmis),          raw_colnames_eng = polyglotr::google_translate(colnames(bra_hrmis), "pt", "en"))  kable(raw_dictionary) ### first let us convert the data to a data.table object to speed up our computations  bra_hrmis <- as.data.table(bra_hrmis)  # Unique CPF per year cpf_summary <- bra_hrmis[, .(unique_cpf = uniqueN(CPF),                              nobs       = .N),                          by = ANO_PAGAMENTO]  # Unique Matricula per year mtr_summary <- bra_hrmis[, .(unique_mtr = uniqueN(MATRICULA),                              nobs       = .N),                           by = ANO_PAGAMENTO]  kable(cpf_summary) kable(mtr_summary) #----------------------------- # 2. Build occupation table (active + inactive) #-----------------------------  occup_df <- bra_hrmis[, c("CARREIRA", "CARGO")]  # distinct CARREIRA/CARGO/status occup_df <- unique(occup_df)  # Add translated vars occup_df[, occupation_native := tolower(CARREIRA)]  occup_df[, occupation_english := tolower(google_translate(text = CARREIRA,                                                           source_language = "pt",                                                           target_language = "en"))]  #----------------------------- # 3. Classify occupations #----------------------------- class_occup_df <- copy(occup_df)[,   .(id = .I, text = occupation_english) ]  class_occup_df <- classify_occupation(class_occup_df,                                       isco_level = 4,                                       lang       = "en",                                        num_leaves = 1)   datatable(head(class_occup_df,                 n = nrow(class_occup_df)),            options = list(pageLength = 10)) #----------------------------- # 4. Merge classification back into occup_df #----------------------------- occup_df[, id := .I]  # merge iscoGroup occup_df <- merge(   occup_df,   class_occup_df[, .(id = as.integer(id), iscoGroup)],   by = "id",   all.x = TRUE )  setnames(occup_df, "iscoGroup", "occupation_iscocode")  # merge ISCO descriptions occup_df <- merge(occup_df,                   isco[, c("unit", "description")] |> as.data.table(),                   by.x = "occupation_iscocode",                   by.y = "unit",                   all.x = TRUE)  setnames(occup_df, "description", "occupation_isconame")  #----------------------------- # 5. Bring classified occupations back to bra_hrmis (active only) #-----------------------------  ## we perform a left join with data.table syntax for speed as the merging into  ## the hrmis dataset could be computationally intensive  bra_hrmis <- occup_df[bra_hrmis, on = c("CARREIRA", "CARGO")] ### lets include the dates bra_hrmis[, ref_date := as.Date(paste(ANO_PAGAMENTO, MES_REFERENCIA, "01", sep = "-"))]  setnames(bra_hrmis, c("DATA_ADMISSAO", "DATA_APOSENTADORIA"), c("start_date", "end_date")) bra_hrmis[, start_date := as.Date(as.integer(start_date), origin = "1899-12-30")] bra_hrmis[, end_date := as.Date(as.integer(end_date), origin = "1899-12-30")]   ### lets include the country code and admin identifier  bra_hrmis[, country_code := "BRA"] bra_hrmis[, country_name := "Brazil"] bra_hrmis[, adm1_name := "Alagoas"] bra_hrmis[, adm1_code := "AL"] ### lets convert the nominal compensation variables to real (_ppp) values # Step 1: Create the _lcu salary variables (in-place, no copy)  ### lets rename the raw variables here to their actual names setnames(bra_hrmis,           old = c("SALARIO_BASE", "SALARIO_BRUTO", "SALARIO_LIQUIDO", "ABONO_PERMANENCIA"),          new = c("base_salary_lcu", "gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu", "allowance_lcu"))   # Step 2: Identify all *_lcu columns to convert cols_to_convert <- grep("_lcu$", names(bra_hrmis), value = TRUE)  # Step 3: Apply PPP conversion using your convert_constant_ppp function pfw_df <-    macro_indicators |>   dplyr::filter(country_code == "BRA",                  year %in% as.integer(unique(bra_hrmis$ANO_PAGAMENTO))) |>   dplyr::select(all_of(c("country_code", "year", "cpi", "ppp")))   bra_hrmis[, (cols_to_convert) := lapply(.SD, as.numeric), .SDcols = cols_to_convert]   ### apply the convert_constant_ppp function to produce those estimates bra_hrmis <- convert_constant_ppp(data = bra_hrmis[, year := lubridate::year(ref_date)],                                   cols = cols_to_convert,                                   macro_indicators = macro_indicators)  ### while we are at this lets include the working hour variable as well bra_hrmis[, whours := as.numeric(JORNADA)] ### create a little dictionary mapping all the raw classes into a contract type in a data.table contract_dict <-    data.table(TIPO_CONTRATO = unique(bra_hrmis$TIPO_CONTRATO),              contract_type = c("short-term", "permanent", "permanent", "open-term",                                "short-term", "inactive", "retired"))  kable(contract_dict) bra_hrmis <- contract_dict[bra_hrmis, on = "TIPO_CONTRATO"] setnames(bra_hrmis,          old = c("MATRICULA", "CPF", "ORGAO", "CLASSE", "NIVEL"),          new = c("contract_id", "worker_id", "org_id", "paygrade", "seniority"))   ### now let us select the final set of dictionary variables to complete the module ### lets use dplyr::select() function since this will not add any computational time bra_hrmis_contract <-    bra_hrmis |>   dplyr::select(     contract_id, worker_id, org_id,     ends_with("_date"),     contains("_salary_"),     contract_type,      starts_with("occupation_"),     country_code, country_name,     adm1_name, adm1_code,     whours, paygrade, seniority   ) ## Rows: 344,920 ## Columns: 24 ## $ contract_id         <chr> "1", "22", "30", "51", "81", "86", "102", "103", "… ## $ worker_id           <chr> "9678b179d65c7d9a40d1eb2f0c687529762fe73ee1e48e768… ## $ org_id              <chr> "GABINETE CIVIL", "GABINETE CIVIL", "SECRETARIA DE… ## $ start_date          <date> 1979-05-01, 1982-08-04, 1981-12-01, 1988-01-07, 1… ## $ end_date            <date> NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, N… ## $ ref_date            <date> 2014-09-01, 2014-09-01, 2014-09-01, 2014-09-01, 2… ## $ base_salary_lcu     <dbl> 13191.07, 705.73, 3841.43, 2100.44, 699.90, 699.90… ## $ gross_salary_lcu    <dbl> 15169.73, 1465.29, 4580.33, 2100.44, 1166.87, 1166… ## $ net_salary_lcu      <dbl> 11474.09, 1465.29, 4369.10, 2082.87, 1166.87, 1166… ## $ base_salary_ppp     <dbl> 3652.4100, 195.4061, 1063.6345, 581.5804, 193.7918… ## $ gross_salary_ppp    <dbl> 4200.2714, 405.7169, 1268.2249, 581.5804, 323.0889… ## $ net_salary_ppp      <dbl> 3177.0039, 405.7169, 1209.7385, 576.7156, 323.0889… ## $ contract_type       <chr> "short-term", "permanent", "permanent", "permanent… ## $ occupation_iscocode <chr> "2149", "9311", "3119", "9311", NA, "9311", "2422"… ## $ occupation_native   <chr> "engenheiro", "auxiliar de servicos dive", "tecnic… ## $ occupation_english  <chr> "engineer", "dive services assistant", "planning t… ## $ occupation_isconame <chr> "Engineering Professionals Not Elsewhere Classifie… ## $ country_code        <chr> "BRA", "BRA", "BRA", "BRA", "BRA", "BRA", "BRA", "… ## $ country_name        <chr> "Brazil", "Brazil", "Brazil", "Brazil", "Brazil", … ## $ adm1_name           <chr> "Alagoas", "Alagoas", "Alagoas", "Alagoas", "Alago… ## $ adm1_code           <chr> "AL", "AL", "AL", "AL", "AL", "AL", "AL", "AL", "A… ## $ whours              <dbl> 30, 40, 40, 30, 40, 40, 30, 40, 30, 40, 30, 30, 40… ## $ paygrade title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: Worker Module standardizes individual-level information employees public sector. section demonstrates harmonization pipeline using contract-level Brazil (Alagoas) HRMIS dataset (bra_hrmis) example. produce clean, harmonized dataset named bra_hrmis_worker conforms Worker Module dictionary standard_dictionary.Rmd. Let’s start little exploration. need understand many unique worker-organization-refdate combinations within data: tells us 334248 unique worker_id-org_id-refdate combinations entire dataset. goal ensure variables worker module added. size worker module remains . , contract module, now add derived variables: remainder variables (tribe, race``) appear missing thebra_hrmisraw data. Therefore, create missing variables (NA`). Finally, can create worker module taking set unique values across set worker modules now created within bra_hrmis. See implementation : Let’s take look bra_hrmis_worker
code: ## how many observations should we expect to have worker_count <-  bra_hrmis |>   dplyr::select(worker_id, org_id, ref_date) |>   uniqueN() ## lets relabel some more variables   # Create the education harmonization dictionary for educat7 education_dictionary <- data.table(   ESCOLARIDADE = c(     "ANALFABETO",     "1 A 4 SERIE DO PRIM. GRAU INCOMPLETO",     "5 A 8 SERIE DO PRIM. GRAU INCOMPLETO",     "1 A 4 SERIE DO PRIM. GRAU COMPLETO",     "5 A 8 SERIE DO PRIM. GRAU COMPLETO",     "SEGUNDO GRAU INCOMPLETO",     "SEGUNDO GRAU COMPLETO",     "ESPECIALIZAÇÃO COMPLETO",     "ESPECIALIZAÇÃO INCOMPLETO",     "ESPECIALIZA«√O COMPLETO",     "ESPECIALIZA«√O INCOMPLETO",     "CURSO SUPERIOR COMPLETO",     "CURSO SUPERIOR INCOMPLETO",     "MESTRADO INCOMPLETO",     NA_character_   ),   educat7 = c(     "No education",     "Primary incomplete",     "Primary incomplete",     "Primary complete",     "Primary complete",     "Secondary incomplete",     "Secondary complete",     "Higher than secondary but not university",     "Higher than secondary but not university",     "Higher than secondary but not university",     "Higher than secondary but not university",     "University incomplete or complete",     "University incomplete or complete",     "University incomplete or complete",     NA_character_   ) )  # Merge the dictionary into bra_hrmis bra_hrmis <- education_dictionary[bra_hrmis, on = "ESCOLARIDADE"]   bra_hrmis <-  bra_hrmis |>   setnames(old = c("DATA_NASCIMENTO", "GENERO"),            new = c("birth_date", "gender"))  ### lets prepare the birth date variables bra_hrmis[, birth_date := as.Date(as.integer(birth_date), origin = "1899-12-30")] ## Warning in as.Date(as.integer(birth_date), origin = "1899-12-30"): NAs ## introduced by coercion bra_hrmis[, c("tribe", "race") := .(NA, NA)] ## lets quickly create the variables that are missing from the raw data bra_hrmis_worker <-    bra_hrmis |>   dplyr::select(worker_id, org_id, ref_date, birth_date, gender, educat7,                 country_name, country_code, adm1_name, adm1_code) |>   unique() glimpse(bra_hrmis_worker) ## what: Quality Control for the Contract Module
title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: function qualitycheck_contractmod() performs comprehensive set checks harmonized HRMIS contract table. ensures required variables exist, validates data types, verifies uniqueness conditions, conducts salary outlier analysis using interquartile range (IQR) thresholds. Key Checks Performed Column existence: Ensures required fields contract_id, worker_id, org_id, salary fields, date fields, administrative codes present. Uniqueness: Observations must unique contract_id–org_date level. Type validation: Ensures character, date, numeric variables correctly typed. Salary Outlier Detection: base_salary_lcu, gross_salary_lcu, net_salary_lcu, function computes IQR-based lower upper bound checks values fall within expected ranges. Logical constraints: whours must 0 60. Country codes must follow 3-letter ISO3 format. ISCO validation: Checks occupation codes occupation names exist official ISCO classification list. title: HRMIS Harmonization
text: Worker-level harmonization requires presence validity demographic, identification, reference date information. function qualitycheck_worker() applies minimal essential validation steps ensure basic integrity worker table. Key Checks Performed Required variables exist: Including worker_id, ref_date, birth_date, gender, educat7, tribe, race, status. Uniqueness: Worker IDs must unique within reference date (ref_date). Non-missingness: Required fields NA. Birthdate validation: Birth dates must fall 1900-01-01 2000-01-01, reduces data entry anomalies impossible DOBs. title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: article describes standard dictionary human resource management information system (HRMIS) data, organized three main modules: Organization, Worker, Contract. modules designed organize standardize information public sector personnel across different countries administrative levels.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Organization module captures information public sector institutions, including ministries, departments, agencies.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Organization Type: Indicates hierarchical level institution within government structure. Ideally, support parent-child relationships, though data may rare practice. Administration Level: Refers geographic/administrative level government (e.g., national, state/provincial, local). Reference Date: Critical tracking organizational changes, mergers, renaming time.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Worker module contains demographic employment information individual public sector employees.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Education Categories: Multiple classification systems provided allow cross-country comparisons mapping international standards. Geographic Information: workers linked organizations, separate geographic fields allow tracking mobility remote work arrangements. Privacy Considerations: module contains sensitive personal information handled according applicable data protection regulations.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Contract module captures details employment contracts, compensation, job characteristics.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Compensation Fields: Multiple salary measures allow analysis gross--net ratios, taxation effects, allowances. Occupation Coding: native standardized (ISCO) classifications enable within-country detail cross-country comparability. Contract Duration: combination contract_type, start_date, end_date provides comprehensive information employment stability temporary arrangements.

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: three modules related follows: One organization can many workers One organization can many contracts One worker can multiple contracts (time concurrent)
code: Organization (1) ←→ (N) Worker Organization (1) ←→ (N) Contract Worker (1) ←→ (N) Contract

title: HRMIS Standard Data Dictionary
text: Temporal Consistency: Ensure ref_date fields properly maintained across modules Geographic Consistency: Country administration codes consistent across modules Unique Identifiers: ID fields globally unique persistent Missing Data: Document conventions handling missing unavailable data Historical Records: Consider versioning strategy tracking changes time

title: HR Analytics Standard Report
text: report provides standard set indicators visualizations HRMIS analytics, building World Bank’s Public Sector Employment Assessment Framework. objective assessment conduct public sector employment compensation assessments can help develop evidence-based reforms. assessment framework consists two parts. first part assesses institutional behavioral aspects employment compensation practices. comprises six dimensions: Wage bill planning. Wage bill controls. Employment levels distribution public sector workforce. Wage competitiveness public sector. Wage equity. Wage incentives. second part assesses impact employment compensation practices : Fiscal sustainability. Public sector productivity. Labor allocation public private sectors.

title: HR Analytics Standard Report
text: designed convenient function, govhr::compute_hrmreport_stats, produces summary statistics necessary produce standard report HR. need provide three standard modules inputs function.
code: library(govhr)  hrm_report_stats <- compute_hrmreport_stats(   contract_dt = govhr::bra_hrmis_contract,   worker_dt = govhr::bra_hrmis_worker,   org_dt = govhr::bra_hrmis_org,   macro_indicators = govhr::macro_indicators )

title: HR Analytics Standard Report
text: wage bill can potentially major effect fiscal balances, simple benchmarks “right” size wage bill. fact, cross-national evidence suggests strong correlation size wage bill fiscal balance. Wage bill dynamics better predictor fiscal sustainability. general, increases wage bill associated worsening fiscal balance. addition, wage expenditures pro-cyclical, rising periods economic growth, falling much downturns due structural rigidity. Guidance questions assessment: wage bill dynamics changes wage bill financed - .e. deficits, raising revenues, reducing expenditures? main drivers wage bill growth? wage bill projections baseline different policy option scenarios based wage bill modeling?

what: Correlation between wage bill growth and fiscal balances
title: HR Analytics Standard Report
code: wagebill_annual <- hrm_report_stats |>   pluck(     "wagebill"   ) |>    pluck(     "wagebill_annual"   ) |>    filter(     indicator == "gross_salary_ppp_sum"   ) |>    mutate(     country_code = "BRA"   ) |>    left_join(     macro_indicators, by = c("country_code", "year")   )  wagebill_annual |>    compute_change(     value,     date_col = year   ) |>   ggplot() +   geom_point(     aes(fiscal_balance, value_growth)   ) +   scale_y_continuous(     labels = scales::percent_format()   ) +   labs(     x = "Fiscal balance",     y = "Wage bill (annual growth)"   )

what: Decomposition of wage growth: employment and wages
title: HR Analytics Standard Report
code: annual_headcount <- hrm_report_stats |>    pluck("publicemployment_share") |>    select(     year,     headcount = summary_value   )    wagebill_annual |>   left_join(     annual_headcount,     by = "year"   ) |>    # filter(year <= 2017) |>   transmute(     year,     `Median Wage (PPP)` = value/value[year == min(year)] * 100,     `Total Headcount` = headcount/headcount[year == min(year)] * 100   ) |>   pivot_longer(     -c(year),     names_to = "Indicator"   ) |>   ggplot_point_line(     year,     value,     group = Indicator   ) +   labs(     x = "Year",     y = "Indicator"   )

title: HR Analytics Standard Report
text: extent wage increases explicitly linked performance important employee motivation public sector productivity. section provide key stylized facts provide evidence productivity fiscal implications pay incentives. include: magnitude promotion-based seniority-based annual wage increases, expected wage increases employee’s career coverage key design features performance bonuses. Guidance questions assessment: wage growth typical public sector employees different occupational groups course career? much wage growth dependent promotions much can occur “within grade”? annual performance management system distinguish high low performers? promotion decisions largely seniority based /automatic? performance bonus schemes occupation groups percentage staff receive ; large bonus staff expected receive? targeted, significant additional pay essential workers serve hard--staff locations rural areas?

what: Allowances as a share of gross pay

title: Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
text: function merges contract information event dataset (hires, terminations, transfers) matching `worker_id` `ref_date`. ensures selected variables contract dataset attached corresponding events without duplicating records.

title: Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
text: event_dt data.table containing worker event records. Must include columns `worker_id` `ref_date`. contract_dt data.table containing contract information, also including `worker_id` `ref_date`. contract dataset provides additional attributes describing worker's contractual context reference date. keep_vars character vector variable names `contract_dt` merged event dataset. typically describe contract-level attributes position, department, employment type.

title: Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
text: data.table identical `event_dt`, specified variables `contract_dt` joined matching `worker_id` `ref_date`.

title: Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
text: function performs *right join* operation `contract_dt` onto `event_dt` (via `data.table`'s `` syntax). unique combinations `worker_id`, `ref_date`, `keep_vars` retained contract dataset prior join, preventing duplicate key matches. function particularly useful enriching HR event logs contextual information employee’s contract time event.

title: Add Contract Information to Event Records — add_contract_to_event
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(data.table)  event_dt <- data.table(   worker_id = c(1, 2, 3),   ref_date = as.IDate(c("2020-01-01", "2020-02-01", "2020-03-01")),   type_event = c("hire", "fire", "hire") )  contract_dt <- data.table(   worker_id = c(1, 2, 3),   ref_date = as.IDate(c("2020-01-01", "2020-02-01", "2020-03-01")),   department = c("Finance", "HR", "IT"),   contract_type = c("permanent", "temporary", "consultant") )  enriched_events <- add_contract_to_event(   event_dt,   contract_dt,   keep_vars = c("department", "contract_type") ) } # }

what: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: function calculates year--year growth rate specified numeric column data frame tibble. automatically completes missing time periods based range date column, ensuring continuous sequences computing growth. Growth computed consecutive years current previous values available. year missing sequence, growth next available year set `NA`.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: data data frame tibble containing variables interest. col numeric column compute growth (unquoted). date_col date year column used order complete data (unquoted).

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: tibble containing original columns plus new column holds computed year--year growth rates.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
text: function uses `tidyr::complete()` fill missing time periods `min(date_col)` `max(date_col)`, `dplyr::mutate()` compute growth : $$growth_t = \frac{x_t}{x_{t-1}} - 1$$ However, growth computed difference consecutive periods equals 1 (.e., consecutive years). time gap greater one year, growth value set `NA`.

title: Compute Year-over-Year Growth for a Numeric Column — compute_change
code: # Example data df <- tibble::tibble(   year = c(2020, 2021, 2023),   gdp = c(100, 110, 130) )  # Compute year-over-year growth compute_change(df, gdp, year) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>    year   gdp gdp_growth #>   <dbl> <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1  2020   100     NA     #> 2  2021   110      0.100 #> 3  2022    NA     NA     #> 4  2023   130     NA

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
text: data data.table containing data. col numeric column (either unquoted string) year--year growth rate calculated. date_col date numeric column (either unquoted string) used order data define time sequence (typically year column).

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
text: data.table : completed `date_col` sequence. new column named `"growth_<col>"` containing year--year growth rates.

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
text: - Missing years sequence added automatically. - Missing values `col` result `NA` corresponding growth rate. - first observation (row lag missing) `NA`. - function can accept unquoted column names strings. - compute growth rates group (e.g., country), subset loop group calling function.

title: Calculate year-over-year growth for a numeric column (data.table version) — compute_fastchange
code: library(data.table)  dt <- data.table(   year = c(2020, 2021, 2023),   gdp = c(100, 110, 130) )   # Using strings compute_fastchange(dt, "gdp", "year") #> Key: <year> #>     year   gdp gdp_growth #>    <int> <num>      <num> #> 1:  2020   100         NA #> 2:  2021   110        0.1 #> 3:  2022    NA         NA #> 4:  2023   130         NA

what: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: `compute_fastshare()` summarizes selected numeric columns specified groups, merges result macroeconomic indicators, computes ratios summarized variables per macro variable, returns either long wide-format data.table.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
code: compute_fastshare(   data,   macro_data = as.data.table(macro_indicators),   macro_cols,   cols,   groups = c("country_code", "year"),   fns,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: data data.frame data.table containing raw data summarize. macro_data data.frame data.table containing macro-level indicators. Must share least one common grouping variable `data`. Default `macro_indicators`. macro_cols character vector column names `macro_data` use denominators ratio calculations. cols character vector column names `data` summarize. groups character vector column names `data` group . Typically includes country date/year variables. Default `c("country_code", "year")`. fns character vector summary functions apply `cols`. Examples: `"sum"`, `"mean"`, `"median"`. output Either `"long"` `"wide"` (default `"long"`). - `"long"` returns tidy table columns: group variables, `macro_var`, `summary_var`, `indicator`, `value`. - `"wide"` returns table one column per indicator original macro/summary values.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: `data.table` containing: - `"long"` format: group variables, `macro_var`, `macro_value`, `summary_var`, `summary_value`, `indicator`, `value`. - `"wide"` format: group variables, one column per indicator (`summary_var` per `macro_var`), original macro summary values.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
text: function works follows: 1. Summarizes `cols` `groups` using functions `fns`. 2. Automatically detects common join variables `summary_dt` `macro_data`. 3. Merges summarized data macro indicators. 4. Computes ratio indicators (`summary_value / macro_value`) combinations summarized columns macro columns. 5. Optionally reshapes result wide format one column per indicator.

title: Compute ratio indicators of summarized variables over macro indicators — compute_fastshare
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{  dt <- contract_harmonized |> mutate(year = year(org_date)) |> as.data.table()   compute_fastshare(   data = dt,   macro_cols = c("gdp_lcu", "pexpenditure_lcu"),   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu", "base_salary_lcu"),   fns = c("sum", "mean"),   output = "long",   groups = c("country_code", "year") )  ## produce results in wide format compute_fastshare(   data = dt,   macro_cols = c("gdp_lcu", "pexpenditure_lcu"),   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu", "base_salary_lcu"),   fns = c("sum", "mean"),   output = "wide",   groups = c("country_code", "year") ) } # }

what: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: Computes summary statistics specified numeric columns data frame data.table, optionally grouped one categorical variables. function supports predefined summary functions (e.g., mean, sum) user-specified formulas. returns results either long wide format, can optionally convert output tibble.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
code: compute_fastsummary(   data,   cols,   fns = NULL,   groups,   output = c("long", "wide"),   tbl = FALSE )

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: data data.table data.frame containing data summarize. cols character vector specifying names numeric columns summarize. fns Optional. character vector list formulas specifying summary functions apply. NULL, default functions defined define_fns() used. - character vector, function names must match defaults (e.g., "mean", "sum"). - list, can contain formulas mix character names formulas. groups character vector specifying one grouping variables. output character string specifying output format. Must one : - "long": produces tall table indicator column value column. - "wide": produces wide table one column per statistic. tbl Logical. TRUE, converts resulting data.table tibble.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: data.table (tibble tbl = TRUE) containing summary statistics group, either long wide format.

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
text: function first matches output argument, loads default summary functions define_fns(), determines functions apply based user input. uses efficient data.table operations grouped computation, optionally reshapes output long format data.table::melt().

title: Fast Summary Statistics by Group — compute_fastsummary
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage: compute_fastsummary( data = contract_harmonized |> as.data.table(), cols = c("base_salary_lcu", "gross_salary_lcu"), fns = c("mean", "sum"), groups = c("occupation_isconame", "year"), output = "long" ) } # }

what: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: function generates suite standardized analytical tables HRMIS (Human Resource Management Information System) reports. combines contract-level, worker-level, organizational data compute wage bill summaries, employment shares, decompositions, profiles occupation, pay grade, organization, education, seniority.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: contract_dt `data.table` containing individual employment contracts variables `worker_id`, `ref_date`, wage variables (`gross_salary_lcu`, `net_salary_lcu`, `base_salary_lcu`), job attributes. worker_dt `data.table` containing worker-level panel data, including `worker_id`, `ref_date`, demographic employment information. org_dt `data.table` containing organizational information (e.g., institution identifiers, types, sectors). macro_indicators data frame containing macro indicators.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: named list `data.table` objects containing: wagebill_shares Wage bill components shares macro indicators. publicemployment_share Public employment share total employment. wagebill_occupisco Wage bill decomposition ISCO occupation group. wagebill_occupnative Wage bill decomposition native occupational titles. wagebill_orgdecomp Wage bill decomposition organization. wagebill_allowshare_paygrade Allowance rate pay grade. wagebill_allowshare_seniority Allowance rate seniority. workerevent Worker-level hiring, firing, retirement events time. employment_decomp Employment decomposition occupation ISCO group. org_decomp Employment decomposition organization. education_profile Distribution public sector workers education, gender, occupation. mobilityprofile Distribution public sector workers pay grade, seniority, gender, occupation.

title: Compute Core HRMIS Analytical Tables — compute_hrmreport_stats
text: function integrates contract, worker, organizational datasets compute standardized HRMIS statistical report. relies supporting helper functions : convert_constant_ppp(), compute_fastshare(), compute_fastsummary(), detect_worker_event(), detect_retirement(). sub-table output list can used directly dashboards, reports, analytical aggregation.

what: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: function calculates ratio (share) summarized microdata indicators macro-level indicators (e.g., GDP, total population, etc.). automatically detects common join keys micro-level summary macro-level data, merges , computes ratios possible combinations summarized macro variables.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
code: compute_share(   data,   macro_data = macro_indicators,   macro_cols,   cols,   groups,   fns,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: data data frame containing microdata summarized. macro_data data frame containing macro-level indicators. Defaults macro_indicators available environment. macro_cols character vector specifying names macro indicator columns macro_data use share computation. cols named list passed compute_summary(), specifying variables summarize (e.g. list(vars = "varname")). groups character vector specifying grouping variables common datasets. Defaults c("country_code", "ref_date"). fns list summary functions passed compute_summary(), typically defined formulas (e.g. list(mean = ~mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))). output Character string indicating desired output format: "long" (default) tidy data frame one row per share, "wide" data frame one column per computed indicator.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: data frame containing computed ratios (shares). output = "long", columns include: Grouping variables (e.g., country_code, ref_date) macro_var, macro_value summary_var, summary_value indicator – constructed name ratio value – computed share output = "wide", ratio indicator returned separate column.

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share
text: function proceeds five steps: Summarizes microdata using compute_summary(). Automatically detects join keys shared summary macro data. Merges summarized macro data join keys. Computes ratio summarized indicator macro indicator. Formats output either long wide form, depending output argument. output always includes computed shares (e.g. employment_per_GDP), well underlying macro summary values used compute .

title: Compute Shares of Summary Indicators Relative to Macro Indicators — compute_share

what: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: flexible wrapper around `dplyr::summarise()` `dplyr::across()` computes one summary statistics set numeric variables, optionally grouped one categorical variables. Users can choose built-summary functions defined [define_fns()] supply .

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
code: compute_summary(   data,   cols,   fns = NULL,   groups = NULL,   output = c("long", "wide") )

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: data data frame tibble containing variables summarize. cols character vector variable names summarize, list element `vars` (e.g., `list(vars = c("var1", "var2"))`). fns Optional. specification summary functions apply: - `NULL` (default): applies default functions returned [define_fns()]. - **character vector** function names (e.g., `c("mean", "sd")`)   referring defaults [define_fns()]. - **list** formulas (e.g., `list(mean = ~mean(.x, na.rm = TRUE))`)   mix character names formulas. groups character vector grouping variables used aggregation. output Character, either `"long"` `"wide"`. `"long"`, reshapes results tidy format columns `indicator` `value`. Defaults `"long"`.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: tibble containing grouped summary statistics. - `output = "wide"`, statistic appears separate column. - `output = "long"`, data tidy (long) format one row per   group-variable-statistic combination.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: function simplifies grouped summaries handling: - Flexible function definitions (`fns`) using formula notation `~expr(.x)`. - Integration user-defined functions via [define_fns()]. - Optional long/wide reshaping tidy analysis workflows.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
text: default functions defined [define_fns()] typically include: `sum`, `mean`, `median`, `cv`, `cp_ratio`. can customized extended modifying `define_fns()`.

title: Compute grouped summary statistics for multiple variables — compute_summary
code: df <- tibble::tibble(   country = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 5),   year = rep(2020:2021, times = 5),   income = runif(10, 1000, 2000),   expenditure = runif(10, 500, 1500) )   # Default summaries by country and year compute_summary(data = df,                 cols = c("income", "expenditure"),                 groups = c("country", "year"),                 fns = "mean") #> # A tibble: 8 × 4 #>   country  year indicator        value #>   <chr>   <int> <chr>            <dbl> #> 1 A        2020 income_mean      1576. #> 2 A        2020 expenditure_mean  955. #> 3 A        2021 income_mean      1636. #> 4 A        2021 expenditure_mean 1190. #> 5 B        2020 income_mean      1166. #> 6 B        2020 expenditure_mean 1161. #> 7 B        2021 income_mean      1517. #> 8 B        2021 expenditure_mean  959.   # Select specific functions  compute_summary(data = df,                 cols = c("income"),                 groups = c("country"),                 fns = c("mean", "sd"),                 output = "wide") #> # A tibble: 2 × 3 #>   country income_mean income_sd #>   <chr>         <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 A             1600.      346. #> 2 B             1377.      280.   # Custom function  compute_summary(df,                 cols = "income",                 groups = "country",                 fns = list("cv",                            q90 = ~quantile(.x, 0.9, na.rm = TRUE))) #> # A tibble: 4 × 3 #>   country indicator     value #>   <chr>   <chr>         <dbl> #> 1 A       income_cv     0.216 #> 2 A       income_q90 1885.    #> 3 B       income_cv     0.203 #> 4 B       income_q90 1668.

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
text: contract_harmonized dataset contains 50,000 synthetic contract-level observations consistent harmonization dictionary "Contract" module. record represents employment contract worker within organization, capturing key information compensation, contract characteristics, administrative geography. records pertain Zambia (ISO3: ZMB).

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized
text: data frame 50,000 rows 21 variables: contract_id Character. Unique identifier contract (e.g., "C000001"). worker_id Character. Identifier worker associated contract (e.g., "W03583"). org_id Character. Employer organization associated contract (e.g., "ORG0194"). ref_date Date. Date contract record entry YYYY-MM-DD format. base_salary_lcu Numeric. Basic pay allowances deductions. gross_salary_lcu Numeric. Total compensation taxes deductions. net_salary_lcu Numeric. Take-home pay taxes deductions. contract_type Character. Type employment contract — one "Short-term", "Open-term", "Permanent". occupation_native Character. Worker’s occupation title native language (e.g., "Comptable", "Analyste"). occupation_english Character. Worker’s occupation title English (e.g., "Accountant", "Engineer"). occupation_isconame Character. Occupation name mapped ISCO-08 classification (e.g., "Technicians"). occupation_iscocode Character. ISCO-08 occupation code (e.g., "2411", "2141", "8322"). start_date Date. Start date employment contract (YYYY-MM-DD). end_date Date. End date employment contract, applicable (YYYY-MM-DD). whours Numeric. Total weekly monthly working hours per contract. paygrade Character. Pay grade salary scale classification (e.g., "G7", "P1"). seniority Numeric. Number years service tenure within organization. country_code Character. ISO 3-letter country code ("ZMB"). country_name Character. Country name ("Zambia"). adm1_name Character. Subnational administrative division name (e.g., "Lusaka Province"). adm1_code Character. Code corresponding administrative division (e.g., "ZMB02").

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized

title: Harmonized Contract-Level Dataset (Zambia) — contract_harmonized

what: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: Convert nominal wages (LCU survey-year prices) real wages expressed 2021 PPP international dollars using: $$Real_{h}^{PPP} = (CPI_t / CPI_{2021}) * (Nominal_{h,t} / PPP_{2021})$$

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: data Data frame columns (country_code, year, wage). cols Column name convert constant PPP international 2021 dollars. macro_indicators Macroeconomic indicators, can lazy loaded.

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: `data_out` augmented columns converted international 2021 dollars.

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
text: Assumes - `data` columns: country_code, year, wage - `cpi` columns: country_code, year, cpi - `ppp` columns: country_code, ppp  (ppp = LCU per 2021 Intl$)

title: Convert nominal wages to real PPP-adjusted wages (2021 base year) — convert_constant_ppp
code: library(tibble) hh <- tibble(   country_code = c("A","A"),   year = c("2010", "2021"),   wage = c(20000, 25000) )  macro_indicators <- tibble(   country_code = "A", year = "2010", "2021",   cpi = c(85, 100), ppp = c(1.5, 3.5) )  convert_constant_ppp(hh, wage, macro_indicators) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>   country_code year   wage `"2021"`   cpi   ppp #>   <chr>        <chr> <dbl> <chr>    <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 A            2010     NA 2021        85   1.5 #> 2 A            2010     NA 2021       100   3.5 #> 3 A            2021     NA NA          NA  NA

Must one "mode", "first", "first_nonmissing".

title: Deduplicate values within grouped data — dedup_values
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:data.table’: #>  #>     between, first, last #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union  df <- tibble(   id = c(1,1,1, 2,2,2, 3,3,3),   date = c("2020-01","2020-01","2020-01",            "2020-02","2020-02","2020-02",            "2021-01","2021-01","2021-01"),   gender = c("M","M","F", NA,"F","M", "M","F",NA) )  dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "mode") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 F      #> 3     3 2021-01 F      dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "first") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 NA     #> 3     3 2021-01 M      dedup_values(df, id, date, gender, method = "first_nonmissing") #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>      id date    gender #>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>  #> 1     1 2020-01 M      #> 2     2 2020-02 F      #> 3     3 2021-01 M

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: Creates returns named list default summary functions used throughout analytics framework (e.g., [compute_summary()]). function defined purrr-style formula (`~`) operates vector `.x` returns scalar summary statistic. returned list can supplied directly summarization pipeline extended users custom functions.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: list includes following summary functions: sum Sum values, ignoring `NA`s. mean Arithmetic mean. median Median value. cv Coefficient variation (requires `cv()` helper). cp_ratio Custom "cp ratio" statistic (requires `cp_ratio()` helper). var Sample variance. iqr Interquartile range, computed `diff(range(.x))`. min Minimum value. max Maximum value. count Number observations. count_unique Number distinct (unique) values. prop_na Proportion missing (`NA`) values. prop_zero Proportion zero values among non-missing data. p25 25th percentile (first quartile). p75 75th percentile (third quartile). p90 90th percentile. sd Standard deviation.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: named list formula functions suitable use `dplyr::across()`, element name function label value one-sided formula computes summary.

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
text: returned list contains commonly used descriptive statistics numeric vectors, including measures central tendency, dispersion, distribution, data quality (e.g., share missing zero values). Users can extend override defaults appending named formulas passing [compute_summary()].

title: Define Default Summary Functions — define_fns
code: # Load the default function set fns <- define_fns()  # Inspect available summaries names(fns) #>  [1] "sum"          "mean"         "median"       "cv"           "cp_ratio"     #>  [6] "var"          "iqr"          "min"          "max"          "count"        #> [11] "prop"         "dtprop"       "count_unique" "prop_na"      "prop_zero"    #> [16] "p25"          "p75"          "p90"          "sd"            # Example usage with compute_summary() compute_summary(   data = contract_harmonized,   cols = c("gross_salary_lcu", "net_salary_lcu"),   groups = c("country_code"),   fns = c("mean", "sd", "cv") ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   country_code indicator                value #>   <chr>        <chr>                    <dbl> #> 1 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_mean 5321.    #> 2 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_sd    880.    #> 3 ZMB          gross_salary_lcu_cv      0.165 #> 4 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_mean   4312.    #> 5 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_sd      764.    #> 6 ZMB          net_salary_lcu_cv        0.177

what: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
title: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
text: Identifies transitions specified job-related attributes (e.g., pay grade, seniority) worker time. function first determines "dominant" contract per worker reference date based decision variable (e.g., highest base salary), detects selected attributes change across time.

title: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
text: contract_dt `data.table`, `data.frame` object containing contract level records. Must include columns `worker_id`, `ref_date`, variables listed `vars`, `decision_var`. vars character vector attribute names (column names) monitor changes (e.g., `c("paygrade", "seniority")`). decision_var string specifying column name used identify dominant contract per worker date (e.g., `"base_salary_lcu"`). decision_fn function defining decision rule selecting dominant contract within worker-date group (default: `max`). Typically `max`, `min`, custom summary function.

title: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
text: `data.table` following columns: worker_id Unique worker identifier. start_date Date previous contract change. ref_date Date new attribute value takes effect. attribute Name attribute changed. Previous value attribute. New value attribute.

title: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
text: function: Sorts contracts `worker_id`, `ref_date`, decision variable. Selects dominant contract per worker-date combination using `decision_fn`. attribute `vars`, compares value previous record   (worker) detects changes. Returns transitions, including attribute name, previous new values,   start end dates transition. function assumes higher values `decision_var` represent dominant contracts `decision_fn = max`. ties occur, first instance selected.

title: Detect Career Transitions Based on Contract Attributes — detect_career_transitions
code: library(data.table) dt <- data.table(   worker_id = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2),   ref_date = as.Date(c("2020-01-01", "2021-01-01", "2022-01-01",                        "2020-06-01", "2021-06-01")),   paygrade = c("A", "A", "B", "C", "D"),   seniority = c(1, 2, 3, 1, 2),   base_salary_lcu = c(50000, 55000, 60000, 40000, 42000) )  detect_career_transitions(   contract_dt = dt,   vars = c("paygrade", "seniority"),   decision_var = "base_salary_lcu" ) #>    worker_id worker_id start_date   ref_date attribute   from     to #>        <num>     <num>     <Date>     <Date>    <char> <char> <char> #> 1:         1         1       <NA> 2022-01-01  paygrade      A      B #> 2:         2         2       <NA> 2021-06-01  paygrade      C      D #> 3:         1         1       <NA> 2021-01-01 seniority      1      2 #> 4:         1         1 2021-01-01 2022-01-01 seniority      2      3 #> 5:         2         2       <NA> 2021-06-01 seniority      1      2

what: A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
title: A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
text: function checks consistency column names across list data frames. returns symmetric difference shared columns (present data frames) union column names (present data frame).

title: A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
text: data_list list data frames check.

title: A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
text: character vector column names shared across data frames. inconsistent unique column names appear data frames.

title: A function to identify inconsistent column names across data frames — find_inconsistent_colnames
code: df1 <- data.frame(a = 1, b = 2) df2 <- data.frame(a = 3, c = 4) df_list <- list(df1, df2) find_inconsistent_colnames(df_list) #> # A tibble: 2 × 1 #>   colnames #>   <chr>    #> 1 b        #> 2 c        # Returns: "b" "c"

what: Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
title: Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
text: function flags values numeric vector outliers fall Q1 - 1.5 * IQR Q3 + 1.5 * IQR.

title: Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
text: x numeric vector.

title: Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
text: logical vector length `x`, `TRUE`   indicates observation outlier.

title: Flag outliers based on the IQR rule — flag_outlier
code: x <- c(1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 100) flag_outlier(x) #> [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE # Returns TRUE only for the value 100

what: This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api
title: This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api
text: function retrieves data Data360 API.

title: This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api
This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api
text: dataset_id Unique identifier database. indicator_id Indicator ID. vector indicators provided, query retrieves indicators. pivot Whether pivot extracted data. Default true.

title: This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api
text: tibble containing data, including country codes, country names,         years, values.

title: This function retrieves data from the Data360 API. — get_data360_api

what: Retrieve dataset metadata from the World Bank Data360 API — get_metadata360
title: Retrieve dataset metadata from the World Bank Data360 API — get_metadata360
text: function queries World Bank Data360 API fetch metadata specified dataset, identified `dataset_id`. constructs request URL, retrieves metadata JSON format, parses R list data frame.

title: Retrieve dataset metadata from the World Bank Data360 API — get_metadata360
Retrieve dataset metadata from the World Bank Data360 API — get_metadata360
text: dataset_id character string numeric identifier specifying dataset metadata retrieved.

title: Retrieve dataset metadata from the World Bank Data360 API — get_metadata360
text: list (data frame) containing metadata associated   requested dataset, returned Data360 API.

                 Please refer to: https://mtimodelling.worldbank.org/resources/MTI_Macro_Econometric_Model.pdf #> 44 The Macro Poverty Outlook (MPO) analyzes macroeconomic and poverty developments in 147 developing countries. The report is released twice annually for the Spring and Annual Meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The MPO consists of individual country notes that provide an overview of recent developments, forecasts of major macroeconomic variables and poverty during 2024-2026, and a discussion of critical challenges for economic growth, macroeconomic stability, and poverty reduction moving forward.\n\nFor further details, please refer to https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/macro-poverty-outlook #> title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: structured metadata dictionary describing variables harmonized across Human Resource Management Information System (HRMIS) modules: Organization, Worker, Contract. dictionary follows SDMX-style documentation standards specifies variable names, identifiers, data types (R), relationships, metadata fields used HRMIS data harmonization.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: tibble 48 rows 9 variables: Concept Name Variable concept name used HRMIS module. Concept ID Short machine-readable variable name used datasets. Description Detailed explanation variable concept. Data Type R data type assigned variable (e.g., character, numeric, Date). Representation (Code list / Format) Expected format, code list, data representation. Primary Key Indicates whether variable uniquely identifies record ("Yes" ""). Relationship Describes relational links modules variables. Module HRMIS module variable belongs : "Organization", "Worker", "Contract". Example Value Illustrative example value variable.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: dictionary integrates HRMIS modules single metadata table. designed use R-based harmonization workflows conforms SDMX Content-Oriented Guidelines (COG) defining concepts, code lists, roles.

title: HRMIS Harmonization Data Dictionary — harmonization_dict
text: SDMX Technical Standards v3.0 — Data Structure Definition (DSD): https://sdmx.org/?page_id=5008 SDMX Content-Oriented Guidelines (COG): https://sdmx.org/?page_id=4345 Eurostat SDMX Metadata Reference Manual: https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/metadata/reference-metadata-reporting-standards

what: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: function standardizes column names data frame using dictionary maps inconsistent time-varying column names standardized set column names.

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: data data frame whose columns need renamed. dictionary Either named character vector (names desired standardized column names values original column names), data frame two columns: `` (original column names) `` (standardized names).

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
text: data frame harmonized column names.

title: Harmonize column names based on a dictionary — harmonize_columns
code: # Using a named character vector dict <- c("age" = "Q1_age", "gender" = "Q2_sex", "income" = "Q3_income") df <- data.frame(Q1_age = 25, Q2_sex = "M", Q3_income = 50000) harmonize_columns(df, dict) #>   age gender income #> 1  25      M  50000  # Using a data frame dictionary dict_df <- data.frame(   from = c("Q1_age", "Q2_sex", "Q3_income"),   to = c("age", "gender", "income") ) harmonize_columns(df, dict_df) #>   age gender income #> 1  25      M  50000

what: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: dataset containing structure International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO-08), published International Labour Organization (ILO).

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: data frame 436 rows 9 variables: isco_version Character. Version ISCO classification (e.g., `"ISCO-08"`). major Character. One-digit major group code. major_label Character. Title major group (e.g., `"Managers"`). sub_major Character. Two-digit sub-major group code. sub_major_label Character. Title sub-major group (e.g.,   `"Chief Executives, Senior Officials Legislators"`). minor Character. Three-digit minor group code. minor_label Character. Title minor group (e.g.,   `"Legislators Senior Officials"`). unit Character. Four-digit unit group code. description Character. Definition title occupation   unit group level (e.g., `"Legislators"`, `"Senior Government Officials"`).

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: International Labour Organization (ILO), https://www.ilo.org/public/english/bureau/stat/isco/

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco
text: ISCO provides system classifying aggregating occupational information facilitate international comparisons harmonization occupational statistics. widely used labor statistics, survey design, policy analysis. ISCO-08 structured hierarchically: - Major groups (1 digit) – broad occupational categories - Sub-major groups (2 digits) – subdivisions major groups - Minor groups (3 digits) – subdivisions sub-major groups - Unit groups (4 digits) – detailed level, individual occupations unit group includes description outlining scope occupation according ILO’s ISCO-08 documentation.

title: International Standard Classification of Occupations (ISCO-08) — isco

what: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: lightweight helper function applies list functions set variables, mimicking behavior `dplyr::summarise_at()`, designed use within `data.table` syntax. useful want compute several summary statistics (e.g., mean, sd) subset columns defined `.SD` `.SDcols`.

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: var vector, list, data frame-like object (e.g., `.SD` inside `data.table` call) containing variables functions applied. funs character vector function names (e.g., `"mean"`, `"sd"`, `"sum"`) list function objects applied element `var`. ... Additional arguments passed function call (e.g., `na.rm = TRUE`).

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
text: named list element corresponds combination variable   function (e.g., `Sepal.Length_mean`, `Sepal.Length_sd`), suitable   use inside `data.table::lapply()`.

title: Apply multiple functions to multiple variables (data.table compatible) — lapply_at
code: library(data.table) iris_dt <- as.data.table(iris)  # Compute mean and sd for Sepal variables by Species iris_dt[, lapply_at(.SD, c("mean", "sd"), na.rm = TRUE),         .SDcols = patterns("^Sepal"),         by = Species] #>       Species Sepal.Length_mean Sepal.Length_sd Sepal.Width_mean Sepal.Width_sd #>        <fctr>             <num>           <num>            <num>          <num> #> 1:     setosa             5.006       0.3524897            3.428      0.3790644 #> 2: versicolor             5.936       0.5161711            2.770      0.3137983 #> 3:  virginica             6.588       0.6358796            2.974      0.3224966

what: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: dataset contains selection macroeconomic labor market indicators multiple countries years. data primarily sourced World Bank World Development Indicators (WDI) via Data360 API. variables renamed convenience, original WDI variable codes provided reference.

title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: tibble 11652 rows 14 variables: country_code ISO3 country code (originally Data360 API). year Year observation (character, originally Data360 API). gdp_lcu Gross Domestic Product (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_NY_GDP_MKTP_CN. pexpenditure_lcu Total government expenditure (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_XPN_TOTL_CN. prevenue_lcu Total government revenue (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_REV_XGRT_CN. taxrevenue_lcu Total government tax revenue (local currency units). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_GC_TAX_TOTL_CN. emp_pop_rate Employment--population ratio (percent). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_EMP_TOTL_SP_NE_ZS. labor_force_total Labor force, total. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_TLF_TOTL_IN. labor_force_advanced_edu Labor force advanced education (percentage total working-age population advanced education). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_TLF_ADVN_ZS. tot_pop Total population. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SP_POP_TOTL. government_expenditure_gdp General government final consumption expenditure (percentage GDP). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_NE_CON_GOVT_ZS. salaried_rate Share employed people salaried (percent). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_SL_EMP_WORK_ZS. cpi Consumer Price Index, total. Original WDI code: WB_WDI_FP_CPI_TOTL. ppp Purchasing Power Parity (local currency units per international USD). Original WDI code: WB_WDI_PA_NUS_PRVT_PP. fiscal_balance Overall Fiscal Balance, USD, percentage GDP. emp_pop population employed .e. `emp_pop_rate` * `tot_pop`. salaried_pop population salaried workers .e. `salaried_rate` * `emp_pop`.

title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: Data360 API, World Bank World Development Indicators (WDI) https://data.worldbank.org/indicator

title: Macro-level World Bank WDI indicators — macro_indicators
text: dataset prepared support wage bill diagnostics fiscal labor market analysis. numeric variables coerced numeric type. Missing values may exist certain countries years.

what: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: function reshapes Data360-style dataset long wide format. spreads indicator values (`OBS_VALUE`) across multiple columns based indicator variable (`INDICATOR`), keeping reference area time period identifiers. resulting dataset renamed cleaned snake_case variable names.

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: data data frame tibble containing variables: - `REF_AREA`: Country region code - `TIME_PERIOD`: Year time reference - `INDICATOR`: Indicator code name - `OBS_VALUE`: Observation value indicator

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: tibble wide format columns:   - `country_code`: country region code (`REF_AREA`)   - `year`: year time period (`TIME_PERIOD`)   - One column per unique `INDICATOR`, containing corresponding values `OBS_VALUE`

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
text: function particularly useful preparing Data360 similar datasets analysis, multiple indicators recorded country year. output dataset cleaned using `janitor::clean_names()` ensure consistent naming.

title: Pivot Data360 dataset to wide format — pivot_data360
code: library(dplyr) library(tidyr)  data_long <- tibble(   REF_AREA = c("USA", "USA", "CAN", "CAN"),   TIME_PERIOD = c(2020, 2020, 2020, 2020),   INDICATOR = c("GDP", "POP", "GDP", "POP"),   OBS_VALUE = c(21000, 330, 1800, 38) )  data_wide <- pivot_data360(data_long) print(data_wide) #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   country_code  year   gdp   pop #>   <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 USA           2020 21000   330 #> 2 CAN           2020  1800    38

title: Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators — wwbi
text: Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators (WWBI) database unique cross-national dataset public sector employment wages aims fill information gap, thereby helping researchers, development practitioners, policymakers gain better understanding personnel dimensions state capability, footprint public sector within overall labor market, fiscal implications public sector wage bill. dataset derived administrative data household surveys, thereby complementing existing, expert perception-based approaches.

title: Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators — wwbi
Worldwide Bureaucracy Indicators — wwbi
text: data frame 993 rows 11 variables: country_code character World Bank country code. year double Year. share_no_edu double Share public sector workers education. share_primary_edu double Share public sector workers primary education completed. share_secondary_edu double Share public sector workers secondary education completed. share_tertiary_edu double Share public sector workers tertiary education completed. ps_wage_premium_edu_sector double Public sector wage premium education sector, compared formal sector workers private sector. ps_wage_premium_hea_sector double Public sector wage premium health sector, compared formal sector workers private sector. ps_wage_premium_female double Public sector wage premium female workers, compared formal sector workers private sector. ps_wage_premium_male double Public sector wage premium male workers, compared formal sector workers private sector. ps_wage_premium_pooled double Public sector wage premium public sector workers, compared formal sector workers private sector.
